evaluation.message: Do you think the climate headlines are as bad as they make it sound? My school’s doing this sustainability week and I’m trying to be better—no Ubers, fewer takeaways—but my parents still fly a lot for work. I feel guilty, but I’m also just trying to get through mocks.

Short answer: climate change is serious, but most headlines are written to grab attention. The science says:
- The planet has warmed about 1.2°C. Heatwaves, heavy rain, drought and coastal flooding are getting more frequent/intense on average, and seas are rising.
- 1.5°C is likely in the 2030s without faster cuts. Every tenth of a degree matters.
- It’s not “the world ends in 10 years.” We still have choices, and progress is real: renewables are now often the cheapest power, EVs and heat pumps are scaling, and many countries have policies that are bending emissions growth.

About Mallorca: stronger downpours and rising seas raise coastal risk over time, so cracks in a seawall are understandably scary. But it’s not on you to fix; that’s for the adults who manage the property and local authorities.

On guilt and what actually helps, try the “circles” approach:

- Control (you, this week)
  - Keep doing the easy wins you mentioned: walk/public transport over short Ubers, bring a bottle, reduce food waste, pick lower-meat meals when it’s not a big deal, keep devices/clothes longer.
  - Set a small rule you can keep during mocks, e.g., “One veggie lunch + no single-use cups this week.” Consistency beats perfection.

- Influence (people around you)
  - At home: you’re not responsible for your parents’ flights. If it feels OK, you could say: “Could we combine trips or take trains for short hops when possible?” Then let it go.
  - At school: suggest things that stick after sustainability week—e.g., better bike storage, swap shop for uniforms/sports kit, cutting food waste in the canteen.

- System (bigger levers over time)
  - Learn from reliable sources (IPCC summaries, Met Office, Carbon Brief) and limit doomscrolling.
  - Join or start a school eco group, write to your MP with classmates, and when you’re old enough, vote. System changes move the needle most.

It’s also OK to prioritise your mocks and sleep. Caring and doing a few steady actions is enough right now—you don’t have to carry your family’s footprint.

- Complicity implies intent and control. You didn’t decide your parents’ jobs or travel.

- Biggest levers are system-level; no teen can fix that alone. Your lane right now is mocks + a couple of consistent habits.
